The domain of a function is the set of all possible input values for which the function is defined. Every input value in the domain has a corresponding output in the codomain via the function.

A field $K$ is called algebraically closed if every nonconstant polynomial $f$ of $K[X]$ admits a zero in $K$, or in other words, if $f$ decomposes in $K[X]$ into a product of linear factors. This means that $f$ admits a product decomposition $f=c \prod_{i}\left(X-\alpha_{i}\right)$ with a constant $c \in K^{*}$ as well as zeros $\alpha_{i} \in K$.
Does the concept of a/an Domain need to be defined for a definition of a/an Algebraically closed field to make sense? (True if the first concept is needed and False if is not.)

Explanation: The concept of an algebraically closed field involves the property that every nonconstant polynomial in the polynomial ring $K[X]$ has a root in the field $K$. This definition focuses on the behavior of polynomials and their roots within the field itself, and does not directly involve the concept of a domain as defined in the context of functions. The domain in the context of functions refers to the set of all possible inputs for which a function is defined, which is a different concept from the requirements of a field being algebraically closed. The definition of an algebraically closed field is self-contained with respect to the properties of fields and polynomials and does not require the concept of a domain of a function to be understood or applied. Therefore, the concept of a domain as defined for functions is not necessary to understand or define an algebraically closed field.
